reviews.review_msg: Its basically a self study course. You go to class to organize how much of the textbook you need to know. There is a lack of answers given out in general and typically you are left guessing till the end. She is great lecturer, but the exams are basically fill in the blanks and wording is always confusing. Should be 5 credits...

I didn't listen to people telling me not to take this course; I thought, how bad can it actually be?? Knowing what I know now, I would not have taken it. Awful, awful, awful. Interesting course that was, unfortunately, poorly taught.

This class requires huge time commitment. The professor is chill, but regrettably unorganized. We got to bring a double sided cheat sheet to every exam, and this class would be impossible without it. Huge amounts of abstract and highly detailed information that seems unimportant. However, if you have the discipline, you can do well.

This is absolutely the worst combination of a insanely content heavy course and a disorganized instructor. She says certain concepts are not important and then tests them on the exams. Worse yet, she stops mid rant with "wait I don't know if that's right, check the textbook". AVOID at all costs! 30+ tests including iclicker, tutorials etc. TERRIBLE

Dr. Scott teaches students how immunology fits in the context of the real world rather than just having you memorize and regurgitate. There's a lot to read, but her exams focus on what she covers in class and you're allowed cheat sheets. She does tend to tangent a lot and is a bit crazy, but overall it's a fun and rewarding class!

Never have I used the textbook as much as this class required me to. Read the textbook, take a day off to do just that. You'll need it. Stick to the diagrams. She bases the quizzes off of diagrams. Cheat sheets are the only saving grace. Don't even try asking HER for help; she'll just tell you to read the textbook. Ask the TA for clarification.

Her quizzes are ridiculous, sometimes exactly like the practice exam, sometimes completely different and has detailed questions. It also has questions from the presentations.  The difficult ones just make the cheat sheet useless. She asks hard follow up questions after each presentation, so be sure to know your experimental methods well.

Be careful for random and/or tricky questions that might pop up outta nowhere on the biweekly quizzes, be sure to do the practice quiz as she recycles some of them(with changes). She might pull out a question from the lecture. Quiz questions come from the presentations as well, so read the summaries. The book is pretty much your new best friend.

You might as well sleep on the textbook as a pillow because it will be with you as long as you're in this course. Do not take unless you can turn comment-like sentences on all 8 exams into comprehensible questions. By the end of the course your motivation for studying will be sucked dry and none left for other course finals. Good luck.

This class is VERY demanding of your time and lecture isn't very helpful. She is always rushed for time, and doesn't cover all the material, yet what she doesn't cover still shows up on exams. She comes off rude, but she's not if you actually talk to her one on one. Your textbook will be your best friend.
SHE IS AWESOME !!!!! but the course is really demanding U just never get to put the book down .. NEVER !!!

Immunology was an extremely difficult course, not because the material's hard to understand but because there is so much to memorize. I actually enjoyed her dry sense of humour and never found her rude, just blunt and to the point at times. She seems to enjoy her career very much; it shows when she lectures.

I would say she is disorganized. When she decided on something (eg. exam date), u can't really object even tho she asked for your opinion. You are required to read the entire textbook as her notes are basically just pictures from the textbook itself.

I have to agree she seemed disorganized but she really knew what she was talking about.  Her goal to get you to understand the bigger picture led to really hard weekly quizzes.  I don't know how I did so well in that class, it is A LOT of work. The way she speaks comes off rude but every timeI spoke to her in person she was helpful and nice.
Although she is quite rude when she talks about things, she sure know a lot about immunology. She is friendly when you approach her. A bit disorganize I would say. But overall she is not that bad.
